<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 114, 606, 139]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 161, 185, 192]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 210, 163, 240]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 203, 400, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[589, 210, 688, 240]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 203, 861, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 263, 170, 279]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 286, 343, 302]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[744, 285, 861, 300]]<|/det|> May/June 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 310, 861, 324]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 354]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 667, 381]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 218, 412]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 850, 577]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 604, 208, 618]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 620, 693, 651]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 686, 863, 809]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 826, 693, 842]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 67, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 97, 91, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 567, 116]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 730, 144]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two identical wooden strips labelled A and B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 156, 875, 174]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(L\) of the wire between the nails on strip A, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 183, 781, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 286, 507, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 395, 876, 414]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 68, 463, 87]]<|/det|>
Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 98, 779, 306]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 327, 509, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 357, 168, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 357, 443, 376]]<|/det|>
F, G, H and J are crocodile clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 387, 876, 421]]<|/det|>
Attach G to the wire on wooden strip A so that the distance \(x\) between the nail on strip A and G is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 432, 166, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 432, 876, 465]]<|/det|>
Attach H to the wire on wooden strip B so that it is the same distance \(x\) from the nail on strip B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 477, 168, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 477, 321, 495]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 507, 168, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 507, 479, 525]]<|/det|>
Record \(x\) and the ammeter reading \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[526, 549, 875, 567]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[528, 579, 875, 597]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 596, 168, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 596, 319, 613]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 610, 876, 628]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 875, 88]]<|/det|>
Vary \(x\) and repeat **(b)** until you have six sets of readings of \(x\) and \(I\). Include your values from **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 92, 645, 120]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{I}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 483, 876, 501]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 510, 138, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 508, 173, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 504, 608, 533]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 510, 876, 529]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 540, 171, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 540, 435, 559]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 540, 876, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 570, 171, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 568, 579, 588]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 794, 875, 812]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 823, 875, 842]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 839, 876, 857]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 685, 87]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(I\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 92, 524, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{I} = Px + Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 126, 386, 144]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 155, 623, 174]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(d)(iii)**, determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 170, 329, 189]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 233, 873, 252]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 262, 875, 280]]<|/det|>
<form>Q = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 279, 876, 297]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 308, 136, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 308, 324, 327]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 329, 534, 377]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{P}{Q} = \frac{\left(\frac{\rho_{\mathrm{A}}}{\rho_{\mathrm{B}}} - 1\right)}{L}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 381, 865, 400]]<|/det|>
where \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) is the resistivity of the wire on strip A and \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) is the resistivity of the wire on strip B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 408, 262, 435]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\frac{\rho_{\mathrm{A}}}{\rho_{\mathrm{B}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 564, 876, 593]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{\rho_{\mathrm{A}}}{\rho_{\mathrm{B}}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[792, 600, 876, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 97, 91, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 734, 115]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillations of a loaded wooden strip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 127, 779, 144]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a rectangular wooden strip with a hole in its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 157, 168, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 157, 875, 189]]<|/det|>
Use some of the adhesive putty to attach the two \(100\mathrm{g}\) masses as near as possible to one end of the strip, as shown in Fig. 2.1 and Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 198, 796, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 345, 507, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 375, 796, 456]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 477, 509, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 507, 166, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 507, 866, 524]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centre of the masses and the hole is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 536, 366, 553]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 599, 876, 616]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 629, 141, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 628, 737, 645]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 797, 876, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 69, 139, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 69, 176, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 69, 875, 102]]<|/det|>
Attach the two \(50 \text{g}\) masses to the other end of the strip so that the distance between the centres of these masses and the hole is also equal to \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 112, 210, 129]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 112, 556, 131]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 140, 804, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 400, 562, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 431, 205, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 431, 875, 463]]<|/det|>
The distance between the string loop and the nail in the centre of the strip is \(b\). Adjust the position of the string loop and spring until \(b\) is approximately \(10\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 475, 203, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 475, 875, 507]]<|/det|>
Adjust the heights of the bosses until the strip is horizontal and the spring and string loop are vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 518, 203, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 518, 403, 536]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 580, 876, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>\(b =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 632, 500, 660]]<|/det|>
